review_title: Still a great experience for newcomers
one_reviews_text: Even in 2022!
2021 and still love this game
The control scheme on the Quest 2 is totally weird, however once you get used to it you will find that this game is awesome. Graphically marvelous even though it's a bit old. Lots of content.

It's a beautiful and creative game, but I tried it back when it was controller-only and tried it once more now that it supports the Touch, but the controls are completely inconsistent and confusing. Mechanics that worked a moment ago at the push of a button don't work a second later or are very specific, teleportation/movement is very akward around the environments, and trying to figure it out makes for a very stilted experience. Wouldn't bother until the controls are a bit more cleaned up, responsive and consistent.

To get nearby the creatures, I am always like "oh s@it it's so beautiful and detailed. What a same, it isn't really playable with quest because of the buttons making some functions impossible to reach. It's a very nice game, if u have the first rift, but on rift s and touch its not that handy to control.

review_title: Just they don't like any food?

review_title: Please Fix it for the Rift S
one_reviews_text:
I have no Oculus Remote (and won't buy one just for this). There is no other game controller connected to my PC, and Bluetooth is disabled (these were some tips I found in the forums). Nothing works. I'm told to calibrate just after the game loads by this somewhat annyoing floating robot, but the Touch controllers just do nothing, no matter how many buttons I press or how I wiggle the joysticks. Very disappointing, it looks like a relaxing game to play.
(I also tried with a controller hooked up, but that did not work either)

This is an amazing little game, and I'm having fun with it, but I might have to give up soon because the controls are not mapped properly to the controllers, so it's impossible to use at least one necessary game function (calling the animals). Also, some tutorials would be good, as it took me ages to work out that the cursor was my view, and had nothing to do with where the controllers were pointed. 

If this is fixed, I will change my rating to 5 stars.

The scenery is good, but the gameplay is lackluster. When I'm about to leave and area, I see a message saying that there are creatures needs that are not met. When I look at each creature, it shows that their needs HAVE been met for the day. There should be a way to limit the number of times your companion robot says phrases. The Tolerons are so annoying. I tried mimicking their moves, but I guess I suck. I got through as much as possible. I believe I unlocked everything ,and it left me bored. I unistalled it.

review_title: Good graphic, but terrible to play...
one_reviews_text:
No good support for the Rift S controller. No virtual hands, bad UI handling.
I only played the game for 5 minutes because the controller support is far too terrible.

This is an older rift title that was designed for the Oculus Remote. You can play it with an Xbox One controller using the d-pad and face buttons while pointing awkwardly with your gaze. The keyboard arrows also work although I don't know what buttons map to the selection buttons (maybe you can use the Oculus Touch buttons for that?). The game itself is beautiful but basic tamagotchi style feeding game. The voice acting direction is pitched firmly at kids: high pitched, obnoxiously condescending and obvious.

Overall a nice freebie that could use an update.

So immersive and fun to play. The story is well thought out and the enviroments are exciting and wll made. The game gets a bit more challenging as you  move along and it keeps your attention as you try to figure out what else you can discover. One of my favorites.
its a good game of fun
I love on very rare playthroughs, after all needs are met for the giffle, they turn gold!

review_title: Doesn't run on my Rift S
one_reviews_text: I gave it one more star than I should have because it looks like it would be a good experience, but I cannot get it to launch.  The farthest I've gotten is that it did start, but the characters said that this would be a good time to califbrate.  Then they stare at me and nothing ever happens.  I tried every button, but nothing ever launches.
Tried so hard to like this beautiful free experience it gave up within 10 minutes due to the horrible screeching robot that never shuts up.
Looks beautiful, but the voice acting, especially on your companion robot is unbareable. If there was an option to mute it, this would be a 5/5 introduction to VR.

Gets stuck in the loading screen. Even after waiting several minutes nothing happened. Tested on Oculus Rift S with its controllers. The game isn't frozen because I can see the parallax effects with the different layers moving when I move.

So since my Rift Touch controllers doesn't work i had to use keyboard, which for some reason works. That wasn't the problem tho, the problem is that my neck hurts from moving and selecting things in this game. That's sad, cuz the game itself looks great :c

Despite the store claiming to, it does not support Rift-S.  Rift-S Touch controllers do not work at all (view point, A select, etc).  An update needs to be done on the Rift-S to pair the Oculus Remote as well, which at least for me (thankfully I managed to get a Remote) would fix the problem entirely.

review_title: Great Game, Bad Mechanics with touch
one_reviews_text: I want to start of by saying this game is really fun, if you have the oculus remote. With touch controllers, its very hard to get around, I was constantly straining my neck to reach my destination. For touch controllers, you have to look the direction you want to go, and hold a button (i dont remember which one) really started to get annoying. In the end, its a really beautiful game, despite the wonky mechanics.

With no options to change the layout its cumbersome.

While more geared for kids, it is very aesthetically pleasing. It feels a bit like playing 1 planet of No Man's Sky with a clunkier interface. I'll probably poke at it now and then just for the nice visuals. I don't have kids, so I don't know if they'd like it. I'm giving it 4-stars for just looking nice and being a simple but good overall VR experience. It's free so it's really hard to complain....

I tried playing this with the touch controllers. I was able to use the left, right, down, A and B controls. However, when I pressed up (call), it performed the down command (book?). This means I was unable to progress with the touch controllers. I tried connecting a Xbox One Controller via blutooth. This disabled the touch controller controls, and the Xbox Controller didn't work either. I had to restart several times, disconnecting and reconnecting the Xbox controller. Somehow I got the right sequence and the Xbox controller worked. However, the perspective was wrong. (I started outside the space ship, landed underground, pressing the "aeriel view" put me underground) I tried resetting the view, and it helped a little, but still wasn't right, but was playable. I think I spent an hour trying to get it working right (searching the net, connecting xbox controller, etc) and was able to play for 10-15 mins. It was an interesting 10-15 min, but now all I can do is fish, and maybe watch for new behaviors. I guess I'll have to play another day to get my next 10-15. I just hope I can get it to work more quickly next time. The graphics were nice, and seemed like an interesting casual game.

(I bought the Marvel Rift set, not sure which generation that is. Not sure if that matters in game play. It might have different touch controllers than some.)

When I first launched the game. They were unresponsive. Closing the game and starting it back up again fixed it. Easy fix. No need to give the game a bad rating cause of that. If they still don't work after that, simply click on the game window after launching it and test to see if they work then.

review_title: Great for people who want cuteness
one_reviews_text: When I demo my Oculus to people, I ask: action, horror, scenic or cute? For someone who wants to look at cute things--the sort of person who spends time looking at kittens on the internet--this fits the niche perfectly. That doesn't happen to be *my* niche, but who am I to judge? You almost certainly already know whether this is for you or not.

I found a thread saying that inthe initial "calibrate" part, just hold the right thumbstick to the left i believe it was while looking around. Tried all directions on both thumbsticks while looking around. Tried all buttons and triggers. Nothing is reacting.

My Touch controllers aren't sleeping as the work fine in the Home menu while Farlands is running, also in Farlands, my Touch controllers active my boundary walls just fine.

In short, if you don't have that original remote thingy or an xbox controller, don't bother.

Overall a fun experience.  The creatures are cutely weird and I love the "live miniature" aspect when choosing a precise spot to teleport into or when returning to the ship.

Intended to be played in small doses rather than all at once -- plants and creature desires refill over a whole real-world day; also the world itself follows a real-time day/night cycle for a bit of variety.  So it will probably take you a few weeks to see all the things.

Designed for the Remote, but does work well with a single Touch controller (though the up/down actions are reversed for some reason).

review_title: No touch support & no touch support...
one_reviews_text: Nice visuals but mosly for kids. While some concepts are educative the fact that we are talking about fictive space aliens make some of the information useless in the long run - A similar game with real animals would be really interesting - even for adults. Note: No Oculus Touch support - wouldn't work with XBOX 360 controller either the first time (now working).

Graphics are still second to none - and the animations, it truly feels like being on an alien planet. Sure controls aren't perfect, I mostly use this app to eperience the environment - simply to sit down and relax. I get perfect 90 fps forcing super sampling 2.0 on a GTX 1080 and i7 7700K. There's no full locomotion, but it's really no problem - use this app to see some of the first attemps to illustrate the greatness of VR. And it's still a shining diamond - not even Seeking Dawn has graphics nor animations like this!
Game based around daily exploration and building on the previous day's discoveries. Visually appealing. Good voice overs.
This game is so much fun if your like me and love aliens and uncharted space!!! I love how you explore a new world and document life and go to new regions i need more games of going to new worlds

In actuality, I have gotten over 100 rare and unusual fish and only 5 common fish. This is an issue. Fix, and I could revise to 5-star.

PROS: Great graphics and animation. Fun, non-threatening environments. Makes good use of built in microphone and positioning. Good overall concept. CONS: Environments are fairly small. Repetitive gameplay. Finicky positioning when you try to join the Kolorons in rituals. Rather than rising to a climax, game tapers down in fun and interest level as discoveries become sparser and sparser.
Great graphics but boring. No oculus touch, not enough interaction.

This was the first title I downloaded for the Rift and although as a game its a bit shallow, the pace and family friendliness makes it a great game to get your VR feet wet. I just wish you could actually move. I hate being stuck in one place. Also, Cloe is as annoying as an extremely annoying thing.
"Why am I doing this?" Thats what I kept asking myself while playing this game. Not that it's **bad**, just, the gameplay isn't compelling.

review_title: I Laughed and Screamed in Terror
one_reviews_text:
For a free title this is easily one of my favorite experiences on the VR because it really draws you in and makes you feel like your on an alien planet, surrounded by strange alien creatures. 

At some points I laughed at the various names of the newly discovered creatures and their behaviors, and a few times I screamed in terror as I would turn around to find one charging right at me, One creature ran through me (extremely unsettling by the way).

But the game is awesome and does an excellent job showing what VR is capable of.
I find it boring and childish for my taste, wish there was a demo before paying for it.

Fun title and excellent for new VR users, especially children and family. Feels very polished, but is ultimately lacking in content. Would love DLC or touch support!
My thoughts in video form: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3n34PwwJSVU .

This is game you play for a little bit and keep coming back to everyday. It feels kind of like a mix of a simple virtual pet game, Animal Crossing and Pokemon Snap. The creatures you interact with have their own personalities and can do some pretty funny things. There's also a little robot that follows you around and helps out with anything you need. She has quite a personality too and doesn't just feel like a voice over. In the game, you're able to explore (teleport movement) around and take pictures of whatever you like.. getting graded on the content, positioning, and pose.. sort of like Pokemon Snap. This helps you progress and open up new areas and items to help interact with the creatures. You're able to pick different food for your creatures and they're able to evolve and gain different colours and needs. You can also give your creatures toys to play with. There are different fish to catch and catalog, as well as different bugs to find and scan. They're trackable with the 3D audio and it works quite well.

It's really relaxing to come into the world every day and take care of the creatures needs, do a little fishing, food gathering, and bug hunting. Farlands is also free so I'd highly recommend checking it out.

awesome graphics
gameplay is a bit confusing and very repetitive though

The creature looked promising in the Dreamdeck experience. But as I played it in the beginning I felt I had opened a bargain-bin activity center from the late nineties... Very dissapointing and kind of a let-down in what I was able to do in the game. The graphics and ideas were neat, but in context it got very lacklustre...
Couldn't believe this was a free game, was beautiful and a great introduction to VR!

review_title: Eh, after Touch it's pretty obsolete
one_reviews_text: It was a cool idea back then. Now I guess it exists to whip out the remote once in a while. This is actually a good guideline - if your Rift set does not include a remote, pass. It's not that it's necessary to play, it's that the game is very... early Rift.
great for learning how to use vr without getting sick. Beautiful Planet and controls. My Favorite game so far!!!! Thanks Devs wish there could be more planets.

to be honest it does lack some excitment every now and again but to me it is very nice to come back home and if i wanna get away to a new world of my own with these adorable silly aliens makes me feel quite content. i love it great job on it.
I think this game show how good you can make games look like in VR. The game itself isn't to bad either even if Im not in the target group of the game. :)

Oculus really dropped the ball here.  Great little experience to play and come back to every day.  I hit rank 10 and everything just stopped, no updates other than bug fixes. Quarterly updates even would have been nice.
...and that's okay. This is a free experience/game when you buy your Rift and it's meant to show off some of what VR is capable of. It does this EXTREMELY well. Play with confidence ya bish.

I never quite understood this title.  It felt about 1/3 of the way toward something like an intergalactic Animal Crossing game... but never really got there.  My understanding is that the game was designed to be something you'd come back to daily over several weeks and see evolve, but I never could maintain much interest in it... particularly as more enjoyable games made it into my Oculus Home library.  Still, being free it's difficult to argue with the price.
touch support would be great
